subsection.name: 2.3 Understanding JAR Files
subsection.p: This sections explains where all the relevant jar files are located. It also lists Cayenne dependencies.

subsection.name: 2.3.1 Cayenne Runtime Framework
subsection.p:
There are two Cayenne JAR files in [cayenne_install_dir]/lib/ directory:
cayenne.jar
cayenne-nodeps.jar
Either one or another should be used (but not both of them at the same time). In most cases cayenne.jar is the best choice. It has Cayenne classes as well as all the needed dependencies. Dependencies are bundled for easier installation and configuration of Cayenne. They include:
ObjectStyle Ashwood Graph Library (see a note about Ashwood below)
Jakarta Velocity Template Engine, version 1.3
Jakarta ORO Regular Expressions package (also bundled with Velocity)
Jakarta Log4J package, version 1.2.8
Jakarta Commons Lang package, version 2.0
Jakarta Commons Collections package, version 2.1
Jakarta Commons Logging package, version 1.0.3
Jakarta Commons Beanutils package, version 1.6.1
If bundled Cayenne dependencies conflict with other packages installed on the user machine, a leaner cayenne-nodeps.jar file should be used. In this case all the dependencies must be installed manually.
subsection.panel: The version of Ashwood library currently used with Cayenne is not officially released as of this writing. In the meantime the correct version of ashwood.jar file can be downloaded from Cayenne CVS, e.g. by using this URL: http://cvs.sourceforge.net/cgi-bin/viewcvs.cgi/cayenne/cayenne/otherlib/ashwood-28012003.jar
subsection.p: cayenne.jar or cayenne-nodeps.jar should be accessible by the applications that use Cayenne. There are a few "standard" ways of doing it in Java, like setting CLASSPATH variable, adding file to the WEB-INF/lib/ directory of the web application, etc.
subsection.panel: It is NOT recommended to put Cayenne JAR files under JRE extensions directory ($JRE_HOME/lib/ext or $JAVA_HOME/jre/lib/ext), though it will probably work for most cases.
subsection.p: The reason for such warning is that classes loaded from extensions directory have their own ClassLoader and can't directly access resources associated with other ClassLoaders. Cayenne allows to "bootstrap" other ClassLoaders for the purpose of resource lookup, but this requires extra code and doesn't solve all problems.

subsection.name: 2.3.2 CayenneModeler Tool
subsection.p:
Java classes and resources used exclusively by CayenneModeler and not required by the runtime are located in [cayenne_install_dir]/lib/modeler/ directory:
cayenne-modeler.jar
scope-bin-1.0.1.jar
forms-1.0.3.jar
plastic-1.1.2.jar
cayenne-modeler.jar implicitly relies on the presence of [cayenne_install_dir]/lib/cayenne.jar. Instructions on how to start modeler can be found here.
